title: How many people in the U.S. will have received one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine as of 31 March 2021, according to the CDC?
preds: Current number of Americans with at least one dose varies between 92 to 95+ million, depending on reporting outlet.  Doubt that there will be more than a few million more doses distributed between now and 31Mar2021
TOO MANY REPUBLICANS SLOW ON THE UPTAKE
The total number of vaccines administered are about 150 million and 50 have received 2 doses.

Reported as of 3/30/21 on https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations:  "People Vaccinated,
At Least One Dose Total:
96,044,046"
as one notable twitter account would say: "I've seen enough".  two more days plus the back log should carry us comfortably into 100m but not over.

My model shows that there should be an additional 7.5 million 1st doses added to the [edit for clarity: current cumulative tally - as at 30th Mar mid-day]  for 30th March, between now and 7th April (AM).
Final forecast figure from my model is roughly 102.5m, right in the middle of the bin.

Last update, affirming 100% for 100-105m. Currently 94.98 (27 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.590 m
Same number of new first shots for 4 more days - 101.34 million.

Updating based on a slightly more careful look at daily average doses administered. Pace of doses delivered would need to increase by about 24% (to ~2.0M/day) in the last week (3/25-3/13) to get above the 105M threshold. That seems like a big jump without any big changes (e.g., in supply of J&J in the last week). Even if there was a big increase in supply, the ability of states to increase numbers with the new supply is probably limited and would ramp up steadily.  To stay below 100M, average daily doses delivered would need to decrease by about 16% (to ~1.35M/day). That could be more plausible with an unexpected shock that limits delivery over a couple of the final days. Or, if there is an unexpected delay in reporting (resulting in many doses administered 3/30-3/31 not reported by the 4/7 data pull) it's possible the final number could drop below 100M. But still low likelihood.

People with at least one dose at 95,015,762 as of 3/29. An average of 2.6 million shots are being given daily. 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends

Earlier, I overestimated how quickly vaccination would pick up. It's just been increasing pretty steadily.
Right now, the CDC website says we're at 95.0M.
Over the next few days, I estimate there will be about 9M to 10M (maybe closer to 9.1M) more vaccinations.
So total for this period will be 95.0M + ~0.5M (J&J) + ~9M*0.65(Pfizer/Moderna, additional people w/ at least one dose) = 101.35M
Additional check from another angle: we were at 82.8M 7 days ago, March 22 => 12.2M added in 7 days => 1.74M added/day; let's say essentially 3 more days of reporting will contribute to the total through March 31; 1.74M/day * 3 days = 5.22M. But, vaccinations/day have been increasing slightly, so we'll get to a total a bit higher than that.
Luckily, 101M is at the low end of the bin. We might end up a bit higher, but I don't think we can end up below 100M or above 105M at this point.
Thank you to all that helped clarifying the question

At the moment around 93,600,000 people have received at least one dose of the covid vaccine and on average 2.71 million covid vaccines are administered per day. Given that there are a few days left and the increasing rates of vaccination, it is possible that the number will exceed 100,000,000 but it also may not. (all numbers come from the CDC covid data tracker)
Currently 93.54 (26 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.588 m Same number of new first shots for 5 more days - 101.48 million.

If daily average remains between 1.5 mil and 1.6 mil people receiving a dose (where it's been for a couple of weeks), based on total as of 3/25 that puts it between 101 mil and 103 mil total. With a couple of states opening eligibility to all adults on Monday 3/29, it seems more likely that the number of people receiving a dose could tick up slightly than go down. But the daily rate would have to go up to about 2.1 mil per day over the last six days (3/26-3/31). That's a pretty big jump, so I'm not very optimistic. (Pls flag if the numbers/math are obviously wrong!) Potential for a drop in the rate could be weather related (e.g., flooding in Nashville), but it doesn't seem like there are big weather problems on the horizon over the next three days. The daily rate would have to go down to about 1.28 mil over the last 6 days; again, that seems like a pretty big change, so I'm keeping both the upper and lower bounds at low probabilities.

Update. I suspect we will probably be at about 98M who have received at least one dose by end of March 31. Then, a few days of filling in the gaps. It doesn't seem likely that there would be more than 7M people added after March 31 as data comes in. That would correspond to about 10M more vaccinations administered. I don't think that many are likely to be added to the tally for vaccinations up to March 31 over the week up to April 7.

Estimating that if this week's vaccination rate picks up 1.14x faster than last week's weekday average (1.14x is a figure I derived from speeding YouTube videos up to a speaking rate which I think could represent the sense of acceleration for working faster with the vaccines), while adding the average weekly growth to today's value in order to get Monday's starting point, it still does not reach 100M. Alternatively, the past 2 Wednesday's have an average growth that still does not take it past 100M. If you apply the same 1.14x principle to the 2-week average (subjective, I know), it still does not reach 100M. And there is still the thing I was talking about, where the count may be lagged a few hundred thousand. And then there is planning fallacy.

Updating. Right now, we're at 93.6M. And when you look at the graphs ("Daily Count" at https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends), it's not clear that by April 7, we'll hit enough to get >105M with at least 1 vaccine. Maybe we'll add up to 1M J&J, and maybe 11M or 12M Pfizer/Moderna; multiply P/M by ~0.65 (calculated from data) to get the number of people with at least one dose = ~7.5M. So unless we drastically increase vaccination rates, it's looking unlikely that we'll get above 105M. We'll probably end up at around 102M to 103M. But, the brackets are pretty narrow....

Currently, the CDC's count of persons receiving at least one dose is: 93,631,163 people. The last day for solidly reported data (not still updating upward) from the CDC is 23 Mar with 88,548,411 people. The current seven day moving average for the last three weeks for new vaccine doses has been approximately 1.55M -1.59M per day. If we assume that the 7 day moving average for at least one doses administered is lower than the actual at 1.5M from the period from 23 Mar to 31 Mar then we would have 88.5M + 1.5M * 8 = 100.5M. If we instead use 26 Mar data which is still being revised upward of 93,537,500 we would get 93.5M + 1.5*5 = 101M. Both are over 100M. It seems very likely that this will make the 100M mark but miss the 105M mark.  Just as a side note the original post does a poor job explaining how to access this data from the CDC website. In the graph on the page linked below select "Metric: People with at least one dose administered" and "View: Cumulative" https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends

Just going by the daily total of "At Least One Dose" on the CDC website (= 93,631,163 as of 3/28/21), it will require an average of around a 2.1 million increase each day to reach a 100 million total as of 3/31/21. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). The recent five-day average increase for this statistic has been about 1.94 million per day.  (Two recent days exceeded a 2.1 million increase, by fairly small amount.) It could be close in terms of topping the 100 million 'at least one dose' total number by 3/31, but at least one of the reporting days remaining (in the question) will probably include numbers from the weekend, which have tended to exhibit lower increases. (FWIW I don't know where to find subsequent "revisions" (- that are specific to a certain (previous) date -) to the "at least one dose" CDC statistic I'm using above..)
feeling decent about the 100m mark, particularly with the wait for the delays. we need a 1.5m/day pace from here on out which should be fine despite the weekend dip

Recently, the cumulative vaccination rate seems to have leveled off a bit on the CDC website, so while I think the number of people with at least one shot will be above 95,000,000, I don't know that the rate will increase enough in the next three days to reach greater than 100,000,000.

Data suggests an overall daily average of around 700-750 individuals receiving at least one shot, however, that daily average recently leveled off and is averaging between 250-400 individuals per day being given at least one round of the vaccine. Data for vaccinations may be lagging in their reporting, but I am not sure if lagging data will have much of an impact as I am anticipating that most of the data is being reported accurately and in a timely manner, which could be foolish being that the government is in charge of this process! source: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends
Currently 91.57 (25 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.578 m Same number of new first shots for 6 more days - 101.04 million. All in.

This Sunday a cold front is expected to arrive on the East Coast where I expect many Americans are eager to get the vaccine. Sundays are already slow and not much vaccines are given compared to the immediately preceeding Saturday. So if this Sunday it's around 92M—slightly higher than Saturday's—and picks back up to the average rate as last week (weekdays only), then it still falls short of 100M. I'm really interested in whether the daily count will start climbing again. As a side forecast, I do not expect it to continue a climbing trend in the next week. However, there may be a link to a climb in the daily vaccine count and the daily number of COVID cases recorded; we are seeing cases rise and therefore, if this hypothesis is true, will also see a rise in daily vaccines. Because of the spike and reasonability of crossing the 100M mark, I increase my probability for this bin. Side thought: Does the J&J introduction have an influence on the relevant data?

Update. Vaccination rates are picking up, but not too quickly. There might be ~15M to 20M more vaccines reported for the month, with ~10M to 13M more added to the number of people who have received at least one vaccine. That would put us at about 102M to 105M, with some possibility of going higher than that.
Reports of a lot of doses being given

Minor adjustment to March 18th forecast: This week is looking to slightly exceed last weeks 1.57M /day
I forecast last full week to average 1.6-1.65M per day
Total range 99-104M

There are about 90M individuals that have received 1 or more doses of the vaccine.  The average per day rate that is being added to this is 1.5M individuals. 90M + (1.5M * 5) = 97.5M These estimates place the total number by March 31st firmly in the 95M-100M category.
Currently 89.4 (24 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.547m  Same number of new first shots for 7 more days - 100.22 million.

Reallocated based on @Anneinak's doubt in reaching 100M in the allotted time. My earlier forecasts were wack because I was crunching the wrong data, but I think I'm starting to settle around 95–100M by March 31. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1254804

There is one more Sunday just before the question closes, as has been pointed out by @probahilliby.  I estimate this will bias the total number down by about one million shots, putting the total slightly over 100M.  I'll stay close to the herd for the final days of this one, unless data revisions push the numbers up significantly tomorrow.

good showing today. weekend typically dips but this shoudl be enough to get us into the 99m range by march 31, and a comfortable +1-3.5m of delayed reporting will take us into the 100-105m territory. barring a massive dump of previously unrecorded data or surprisingly anemic last few days, we are locked in.

The trends regularly stall around weekends. About half of the days remaining are part of the weekend stall I expect. With this, in addition to the count delay, it could be below 100M. However, this week showed an impressive climb.

Data revisions keep adjusting old numbers up. Given the preliminary numbers for the past few days, I'm very confident that we won't see a significant drop in rate next week. This question should close at right around 101M

Currently 87.192 (23 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.527m (trend of that: slightly down). Same number of new first shots for 8 more days - 99.41 million.  This will be one of the closest outcomes in history.

revising due to lower than expected data coming in. with another new day of data, we have 6 more days left and the hurdle to 100m+ gets just a little higher. 2.11m avg needed in the remaining days. typically tmw and next day are blockbuster days of the week so these will need to be strong days and we will need to rely on the stragglers after 3/31 to get over the 100m hump. still pretty optimistic for 100-105 but revising downwards.
Now that more pharmacies have access to the vaccine, people are more likely to go and get one because all you have to do is sign up on their websites.
Over the past month 1.5M individuals have been added to the one or more doses each day.  There are 7 days remaining until the end of March.  85.5M individuals currently + (1.5M * 7) = 96M total
Currently 85.3 (22 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.518m (trend of that: slightly down). Same number of new first shots for 9 more days - 98.96 million.

I estimate near the ballpark of 100M but I am considering the decline of testing in recent weeks even with the count delay. Speaking of count delay, I factor this in, in deciding that the count a week later might be below the projection of 100M (approx). The +3pp in the past 24 hrs in this bin has also weakened my confidence in the 100–105M bin. Though I do understand as cases rise ever so slightly in the US, that could correlate with an increase in testing. Or is it the opposite? Does less testing mean more cases (as preached  by Dr. Sanjay Gupta on CNN)? With that hypothesis, my current assumption holds.

There are 7 reporting days left before April 1. The count stands at 85.48m. An avg of 2.07m is needed from here on out to reach the 100m threshold and every day under that increases the bar a bit more. It will be close to that. Probably slightly under by 0-2m or so. However, after the March 31 date is reached, there will be a number days for lagging reports that come in during April. It seems to take about 5 days for all those to come in so I anticipate another 1m-3m or so on top of the total. On balance I think this pushes us over into the 100-105 bucket but not so far as to be in the 105+ bucket
Upon further review of past data, mean estimate is 101.4M.

Counting from the date reported to 19th when the data is mostly complete from it needs 1.6m per day.  Current rolling trend is very just below that so still think the outcome will be very close to 100m, but am weighting heavily to below 100m.  My forecast current gets to 98.5m

Update/back of the envelope check for 3/26 am:
87.3M people have received at least one dose.
18.2M Pfizer and 20.1M Moderna vaccines delivered but not yet administered => total 38.3M P/M vaccines on hand.
2.1M J&J vaccines delivered but not yet administered.
From what I gather, most vaccine appts are made a week ahead. So, given the reporting lag, those are probably the ceilings for vaccines that will be distributed over the coming week.
Then upper bound for # of people receiving at least one dose for the week approx = 87.3M + 2.1M (J&J) + 38.3M * 0.65 (P/M; about 65% are currently given to people receiving the first dose) = 114.3M
Still too hard for me to forecast better without a detailed model.
Fri., Sat. & Sun. are typically the biggest reporting days of the week, so I'll wait for those.
Oops!  I just figured out the thing about data revisions.  That's going to add a couple of million first doses to the 3/31 data.  My bad.

Capacity, delivery sites/processes, etc. are dialing into that 100M range. If any real surprise, it would be to the upside. It seems the administration and CDC would "just love" to hit that 100M mark.

Currently 83.85 (21 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.528m (trend of that: slightly down). Same number of new first shots for 10 more days - 99.13 million. 
Holy cow, this will be close between bins 7 and 8. Could be a matter of a handfull of people reported on 6 April. But: no risk, no fun.
An average of over 2M first doses per day must be administered over the next 8 days to reach 100M.  It's not impossible, but it seems unlikely based on recent trends.  I'm all-in for 95M to 100M.

If sustained the most recent 20-day average (increase) of 1,553,556 new "one or more doses" per day would not achieve the 100 million number by 3/31/21. (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations)  As of 3/23/21 a daily average increase to the statistic of around two million/day will probably be needed to reach 100 million+
The data seem to be trending toward a mean estimate of right around 100M. It's not clear quite yet on which side the numbers will fall.

The distribution capability is limited to three companies who want to maintain proprietor rights which limits third-party production. The distribution process is complicated due to temperature requirements and special handling. There are also challenges with distribution which have required federal assistance through FEMA and the National Gaurd. The last point is the drug is still experimental leaving a large percentage of the population skeptical.
Currently 82.74 (20 March), 7-day moving average of new first shots 1.524m (trend of that: slightly down). Same number of new first shots for 11 more days - 99.5 million

Update of previous forecast (text appended below) to fix errors. To add to last week's CDC totals: add (0.3M + 0.5M + 0.9M + 0.7M + 0.8M - 0.2M (J&J)) * 0.65 (Pfizer/Moderna) + ~0.2M (J&J)
= 2.15M This week (March 22 to 28): Total Pfizer + Moderna doses on hand, according to the CDC, =~28.5M. ~2.45M/day (extrapolated) * 7 = 17.2M. Big gap! But, places are opening up large vaccination clinics. It's possible! If 2.45M/day, then 2.45M/day * 7 days * 0.64 (at least one dose) = 11.0M additional people who have had at least one dose. If 28.5M doses, then, say, 28.5M * .75 (at least one dose) = 21.4M (could be higher). But, would take 28.5M/7 = 4.1M doses/day, which is not plausible. So, about 11.0M to 21.4M additional people who have had at least one dose, with higher numbers less likely. Next week (March 29 to 31): Total Pfizer + Moderna on hand for 3 days could be, say, 9M or 10M. If 2.6M/day (Mon. to Wed., average is approx. weekly average), then 2.6M/day * 3 days * .64 (at least one dose) = 5.0M additional people who have had at least one dose. If, say, 10M doses given, then, say, 10 * .75 (at least one dose) = 7.5M (could be higher). So, 5.0M to, say, 7.5M additional people who have had at least one dose, with the higher end less likely. Total number of people who will have had at least one dose of vaccine by 3/31
= 82.8M (reported 3/22) + 2.15M (adjustment for last week) + (11.0M to 21.4M for Pfizer/Moderna this week) + (5.0M to 7.5M for Pfizer/Moderna the last 3 days of March) + (1.3 to 2.5M for J&J)
= 102.3M to 116.4M I'll be very surprised if fewer than 100M have had at least one dose by March 31. I'll be shocked if fewer than 95M. There could be very large vaccine deliveries this week. And, it's possible that more than 70% of the people who get vaccines this week and next will be getting their first dose. More than 105M is quite possible. To get to 115M by 3/31, an additional 32.2M more people would need to receive at least one dose by then. If the numbers of such people represent 65% of all vaccinations, we'd need to give 50M more vaccines by March 31, or ~5M/day. I just don't see that happening. Even if the numbers of such people represent 90% of all vaccinations, we'd need to give 35.8M more vaccinations by 3/31, or ~3.6M/day between now and then. That also doesn't seem likely. To get to 110M by 3/31, 27.7M more => 27.7M/0.65 = 42.6M => 4.3M doses/day. 27.7M/0.9 = 30.8M => 3.1M doses/day on average. Also doesn't seem likely. But if there were really big deliveries, it wouldn't be impossible. ******* Previous text: According to the CDC, as of 3/22/21, 82.8M people in the US have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). Assuming a reporting lag of at most 1 week, the 7-day moving average of doses administered/day was at about 1.55M/day a week ago. It has generally been going up, as more doses become available. I can extrapolate the CDC vaccine administration curves to ~1.8M vaccines/day average for last week, ~2.1M vaccines/day average for the coming week, and ~2.4M vaccines/day for March 29-31, all with giant error bars that make these predictions difficult. Then total additional vaccines given by March 31 to be reported by April 7, 2021 = approx. (0.25M * 7) + (2.1M * 7) + (2.4M * 3) = ~23.7M more vaccines. Let's say in the ballpark of 50% of the people who will have had at least one vaccine dose will have had only one dose by March 31. An absolute lower bound on the number of people who have received at least one dose is today's figure of 82.8M. With the assumption of continuing trends as they are, a reasonable upper bound is 82.8M + 24M (if all subsequent doses went to people who have not received a first dose) = ~107M. Are these estimates reasonable given what we know about upcoming vaccine deliveries? Many locations have stated that the limiting factor in getting vaccines into arms has been the availability of vaccines rather than of distribution. Moderna, Pfizer and J&J plan to deliver a combined total of 240M cumulative doses by the end of March (https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/01/health/covid-vaccines-coming-when-trnd/index.html). Not all shots will be in arms by then. If they were all in arms by then, and ~50% had received only 1 dose, then 20M (J&J) + 220M*(2/3) (Pfizer/Moderna) = in the ballpark of 167M would have received at least one shot. How many vaccines have already been delivered? As of 3/22/21, 152.5 Pfizer/Moderna and 4.3M J&J (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). it seems unlikely that Pfizer and Moderna will deliver a combined additional ~70M vaccines in the next ~10 days, or that J&J will deliver an additional ~16M. In any case, it seems unlikely that 86M additional vaccine doses could be administered in the next ~10 days (taking into account lags for reporting). A jump to 8M+ doses/day does not seem reasonable to me. A total of 124.0M Pfizer/Moderna and 2.4M J&J vaccines have been administered (https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations). Administration always lags delivery, but not enormously. And as vaccination rates increase, the percentage that has received only one vaccination (Pfizer/Moderna) will also increase. J&J: 2.4M doses given, and ~1.85M delivered doses remain to be administered. Let's suppose, optimistically, that ~3M additional J&J doses are administered by 3/31. Then total J&J = ~5.4M. Below, approximations for Pfizer/Moderna: Pfizer: 63.7M doses given, 22.2M fully vaccinated, 19.4M with one dose only (30.5% of total administered), 41.5M with at least one dose (65.1% of total administered), and 13.3M delivered doses remain to be administered. Moderna: 63.7M doses given, 20.3M fully vaccinated, 19.6M with one dose only (30.8% of total administered), 40.0M with at least one dose (62.8% of total administered), and 15.2M delivered doses remain to be administered. Vaccination appointments in many (most?) places are made at most 1 week in advance. Then bumping up reporting for last week: add 0.2M * 7 * 0.64 = 0.90M additional people who have had at least one dose. Say 1.0M to include J&J. This week: Total Pfizer + Moderna doses on hand, according to the CDC, =~28.5M. ~2.1M/day (extrapolated) * 7 = 14.7M. Big gap. But, places are opening up large vaccination clinics. It's possible! If 2.1M/day, then 2.1M/day * 7 days * .64 (at least one dose) = 9.4M additional people who have had at least one dose. If 14.7M doses, then, say, 14.7 * .75 (at least one dose) = 11.0M (could be higher). So, 9.4M to, say, 12M additional people who have had at least one dose. Next week: Total Pfizer + Moderna on hand for 3 days could be, say, 6 to 10M. If 2.4M/day (Mon. to Wed.), then 2.4M/day * 3 days * .64 (at least one dose) = 4.6M additional people who have had at least one dose. If, say, 8M doses given, then, say, 8 * .75 (at least one dose) = 6M (could be higher). So, 4.6M to, say, 6M additional people who have had at least one dose. Total number of people who will have had at least one dose of vaccine by 3/31
= 82.8M (reported 3/22) + 1.0M (adjustment for last week) + (9.4M to 12.0M for Pfizer/Moderna next week) + (4.6 to 6M for Pfizer/Moderna the last 3 days of March) + 3M (J&J)
= 100.8M to 104.8M
= ~101M to 105M I'll be surprised if fewer than 100M have had at least one dose by March 31. I'll be shocked if fewer than 95M. There could be very large vaccine deliveries this week. And, it's possible that more than 70% of the people who get vaccines this week and next will be getting their first dose. More than 105M is quite possible. To get to 115M by 3/31, an additional 32.2M more people would need to receive at least one dose by then. If the numbers of such people represent 65% of all vaccinations, we'd need to give 50M more vaccines by March 31, or ~5M/day. I just don't see that happening. Even if the numbers of such people represent 90% of all vaccinations, we'd need to give 35.8M more vaccinations by 3/31, or ~3.6M/day between now and then. That also doesn't seem likely. To get to 110M by 3/31, 27.7M more => 27.7M/0.65 = 42.6M => 4.3M doses/day. 27.7M/0.9 = 30.8M => 3.1M doses/day. Also doesn't seem likely. But if there were really big deliveries, it wouldn't be impossible.

Next week: Total Pfizer + Moderna on hand for 3 days could be, say, 6 to 10M. = 100.8M to 104.8M

To get to 115M by 3/31, an additional 32.2M more people would need to receive at least one dose by then. Even if the numbers of such people represent 90% of all vaccinations, we'd need to give 35.8M more vaccinations by 3/31, or ~3.6M/day between now and then. That also doesn't seem likely. To get to 110M by 3/31, 27.7M more => 27.7M/0.65 = 42.6M => 4.3M doses/day. 27.7M/0.9 = 30.8M => 3.1M doses/day. Also doesn't seem likely. I did an integral under the curve of daily shots to forecast a quadratic function of cumulative shots of 147.7M shots by 3/31. That is 54.0M more shots than on 3/9. There are 28.9M people who have received a single dose. I assumed 80% of those people will get a second shot in the next 21 days (3 weeks for Pfizer, 4 weeks for Moderna, no second shot for J&J). That implies 30.9M new people getting shots by end of March to get to 147.7total jabs. That means 61.1M+30.9M = 90.1M people with at least one shot. I put a 10% standard deviation on the incremental 29.0M people to receive a first shot. Then I just took the percentages from a CDF of a normal distribution function based on total people with at least one dose.

Just a simple extrapolation suggests we would land around 100m. Given the increasing accessibility, it's tempting to use a more aggressive linear growth assumption. However, given that people only get counted once, that assumption is not wise. Because the pool of people needing and wanting vaccinations will shrink by one with every administered dose, the administration rate will slow. The question is when it will peak.  It seems unlikely that the rate will fall dramatically as access increases. But, we are yet to see how many young and healthy people will get the shot. I'll watch the numbers over the next few days, but I'm centering my guess around the 90-100M mark to start.

The current seven day running average for new people to receive at least a single COVID-19 vaccine dose is 1,194,785, showing a steady upward trend since 23 February 2021.  In the past seven days, the trend has shown an average increase of 64,422.45 people over the past seven days.  At the current rate of this trend, there would be 88,287,102 people having received at least one dose of the vaccine by 31 March 2021.  If the number of new people receiving vaccinations remains the same instead of increasing, the number will reach 86,612,118 in the same time frame.  Johnson & Johnson plans to deliver 20 million doses of their vaccine throughout the U.S. in March 2021, adding to the supply.  This will have a positive impact on the supply of vaccines, especially since it requires only one dose as opposed to other vaccines which require two.  Issues which could have a negative impact on the ability to vaccinate new people include public willingness and supply chain issues.  Based on this information, I believe the number of people having received at least one dose of the COVID-19 vaccine in the U.S. as of 31 March 2021 is most likely between 85 and 95 million people, assigning a 28% chance to each 5 million range.  I believe the numbers are more likely to exceed my prediction than to fall below it due to the priority placed on vaccination by the federal administration.

According to the CDC Data Tracker, NPR’s COVID-19 Vaccine Tracker, and Bloomberg’s COVID-19 Vaccine Tracker, as of March 6th, around 87.9 million doses have been administered to the American people, making up about 17.3% of the total US population. More than 29.7 million have received two doses, and over 57.3 million have received one dose. There have been 116,355,405 vaccines delivered across the country according to the CDC, and in the past week, 2.16 million doses were administered on average per day. According to the New York Times tracker, the average number of vaccine doses given per day seems to be on an overall upward slope since they began rolling out vaccines in December. Today is March 6th, meaning there are 25 days before the 31st. With around 2.16 million vaccines being administered daily, there will be roughly 53.95 million more vaccines administered by the 31st. Adding this to the number of people who have received one or more doses, roughly 111,309,349 people will have received one or more doses by the end of the month. However, I started thinking that some of these 53.95 million doses will be administered to people getting their second shot, which will not add to the total number of people who have received one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine. So, I had to reevaluate and calculate how many people will be receiving their first dose over the next 25 days. According to the New York Times tracker, over the last week, 1,274,759 first doses were administered on average per day. Doing the math, this means that roughly 31.86 million people will receive their first vaccine by the 31st, adding up to a total of 89,227,824 people who will have received one or more vaccines by the end of the month. The newly approved Johnson & Johnson vaccine is not yet recorded in CDC data, so this might lend to more cases recorded over the next month. Given this calculation and the fact that the daily average number of doses is steadily rising every day with the US having the ultimate goal of administering 3 million shots on average per day, I am giving a 0% chance of fewer than 90 million; 5% chance of between 90 million and 95 million inclusive; 40% chance of more the 95 million but fewer than 100 million; 40% chance of between 100 million and 105 million inclusive; 8% chance of more than 105 million but fewer than 110 million; 5% chance of between 110 million and 115 million inclusive; and a 2% chance of more than 115 million people in the U.S. receiving one or more doses of a COVID-19 vaccine by 31 March 2021.

The 'One or more doses' element of the question continues to leave some uncertainty around how to forecast the progress. There are three figures of note:
1) Total doses given
2) Receiving 'One or more doses'
3) Receiving 2nd dose 
Assume that 1) = 2) + 3)
[Thanks to @Anneinak for her feedback !]
I'm using a couple of other assumptions on this forecast:
-Simplify the term 'One or more doses' to mean people receiving their first dose only, and not including the second dose. These 'One+ dose and the '2nd dose' figures stack up relatively closely to monitor the 'total doses given' so there is strong correlation that we're using the right numbers !
-'Total doses given' figure continues to rise, trending at a increase of about 200K doses per week on over the last 5-6 weeks... steady operational progress
-Between 24th January and 15th February, as the vaccination programme got rolling and found a groove, the 'One or more doses' daily figure topped out at a steady 7-day moving average of ~930K 'One or more doses' per day, which likely represents something close to a significant operational limitation give or take 10% either way.
-The 'people receiving dose 2' figure continues to rise as more people are 'eligible' which will include a larger proportion of the 'Total Doses given' figure
-The weather conditions from mid-February showed a decline in all the three figures, with operational hurdles. The last week of February showed a gargantuan effort by the entire programme to 'catch up for lost time' and 'Total doses given' average over the last 2 weeks of February were similar to 'Total doses given' before the mid-February storm.
-Note: the 'Vaccination Trends' tab provides an interesting look at weekly trends, including the 'Sunday slowdown' effect.  See  https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends
-I will assume that there will be a continued increase in 'Total doses given', with a growing proportion being '2nd doses'.
-A daily moving average for 'One or more' doses of between  910K and 1.1M dose per day will result in between 80-85 M 'One or more' doses given, which I believe is the most likely outcome.
